Inspectorate 
	The Attorney General shall appoint a person as Her Majesty’s ChiefInspector of the Crown Prosecution Service.
	The Chief Inspector may appoint inspectors and other staff to assist him inthe discharge of his functions.
	There shall be paid out of money provided by Parliament—
		such sums in respect of salary, pension, allowances and compensation forthe Chief Inspector as the Attorney General may determine, and
		expenditure incurred by the Chief Inspector in the discharge of hisfunctions, including expenditure on payments to or in respect of staff.
Functions 
	The Chief Inspector shall—
		inspect or arrange for the inspection of the operation of the CrownProsecution Service,
		report to the Attorney General on any matter connected with the operationof the Service which the Attorney General refers to him, and
		submit an annual report to the Attorney General on the operation of theService.
	The Attorney General shall lay before Parliament a copy of any report whichhe receives under subsection (1)(c).
	The Chief Inspector may designate an inspector to discharge his functionsduring any period when he is absent or unable to act.
Short title, commencement and extent
	This Act may be cited as the Crown Prosecution Service Inspectorate Act2000.
	Sections 1 and 2 shall come into force on such day as the Attorney Generalmay appoint by order made by statutory instrument.
	This Act shall extend to England and Wales only.
